prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Olive Green
Description: An art-school student whose ambition is to become an artist. She's just regained consciousness, having been comatose for days after suffering a stab to from the back.
Character 4
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime.↳A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime, but now finds himself accused of another.
Character 5
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 6
Name: William Shamspeare
Description: The victim of the current case - a failed actor renting a room in the same building as Mr Natsume's lodgings.
Character 7
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 9
Name: Adron B. Metermann
Description: A young man who works for Altamont Gas. He's a witness to the incident.
Character 10
Name: Quinby Altamont
Description: The wife of the owner of the Altamont Gas Company. She's a staunch believer in the superiority of the fuel and utterly unforgiving of gas theft.
Character 11
Name: Duncan Ross
Description: The love of Miss Green's life, who sadly passed away a month ago as a result of gas poisoning.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt for some books that Mr Natsume purchased at a secondhand bookshop. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 2
Name: Nearby Street Map
Description: A street map of the neighbourhood where Mr Natsume has his lodgings. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 3
Name: Pair of Teacups
Description: The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup.
Evidence 4
Name: Torn-Off End of Envelope
Description: A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. The rest of the envelope could not be located. A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It fits perfectly with an envelope in Miss Green's possession.
Evidence 5
Name: Bar of Soap
Description: A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. It's one of two that were found there. A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. There is a two centimetre diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police upon their arrival. The victim can be seen unconscious at the table, having been poisoned.
Evidence 7
Name: Victim's Medical Report
Description: A report issued by Scotland Yard's medical officer. It obviously mentions the poison as well as other details gleaned during the police investigation.
Evidence 8
Name: Gas Meter
Description: A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. It sports a very strong lock, especially with Mr Shamspeare in mind. A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. The attached coin box sports a very strong lock, and there is a tiny hole in its base.
Evidence 9
Name: Handprints on the Wall
Description: Traces of handprints on the wall, discovered using the Skin Print Seeker gun. There are multiple prints on either side of a hanging picture.
Evidence 10
Name: Capital Offender Article
Description: A newspaper article about Selden, a criminal sentenced to receive the death penalty. However, he died of illness in prison whilst his loot remained undiscovered.
Evidence 11
Name: Hidden Photograph
Description: A photographic print found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It shows the landlord, Mr Garrideb, together with a young man.
Evidence 12
Name: Bottle of Poison
Description: A bottle found in the possession of Miss Green with traces of the slow-acting poison strychnine inside.
Evidence 13
Name: Capital Offender's File
Description: Scotland Yard's file about the convicted criminal Selden that includes the newspaper article about him dying of illness in prison.
Evidence 14
Name: Miss Green's Card
Description: A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. It contains instructions to meet with someone who claims to have information about Duncan Ross. A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. The envelope fits perfectly with a torn-off piece found at the scene of the crime.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It was around nine o'clock that evening when I visited my neighbour, and I took some tea with me as a gift.
Person: Soseki
Testimony 1
Testimony: We had a heated literary debate over a nice, hot drink. After which I went back to my room, at around eleven.
Person: Soseki
Testimony 2
Testimony: Argh! My tea was completely harmless! He couldn't have locked the door behind me otherwise, could he?
Person: Soseki
Testimony 3
Testimony: Strychnine takes some time to have an effect on the body. People don't keel over immediately after takin' it.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: The victim would have been perfectly able to lock the door after his guest left. The argument still stands.
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through the characters, evidences, and testimonies provided.

First, the characters involved include Susato, Iris, Sholmes, Olive Green, Soseki Natsume, Gregson, William Shamspeare (the victim), Garrideb, etc. The case seems to involve Soseki being accused of a crime, possibly related to the death of Shamspeare through poisoning.

Looking at the evidences:

- Evidence 3: Pair of Teacups. The description mentions that Mr. Natsume's cup (with a green rim) has no tea ring on the inside. This might suggest that he didn't drink from it, or maybe the tea wasn't consumed. 

- Evidence 12: Bottle of Poison (strychnine) found with Olive Green. Strychnine is a slow-acting poison, so if someone used this, the victim wouldn't die immediately.

Now the testimonies from Soseki (the defendant) and Gregson (the detective):

Testimony 0 (Soseki): He visited his neighbor (probably Shamspeare) around 9 PM with tea as a gift. They had a debate over tea, and he left at 11 PM.

Testimony 2 (Soseki): He argues that his tea was harmless, and the victim couldn't have locked the door after him if he was already poisoned. 

Testimony 3 (Gregson): Strychnine takes time to act, so the victim could still lock the door after Soseki left.

Wait, the key point here is the timeline and the poison's effect. If Soseki gave Shamspeare a poisoned tea, and the poison is slow-acting (as Gregson states), then Shamspeare could indeed lock the door after Soseki left, contradicting Soseki's claim that the tea was harmless. However, the contradiction might be elsewhere.

Looking back at the teacups (Evidence 3). If Soseki's cup has no tea ring, that suggests he didn't drink from it. But if he gave tea as a gift, maybe the victim drank it. But if the poison was in the tea, then the victim would have consumed it. However, Soseki says his tea was harmless, so maybe the poison was elsewhere?

Alternatively, maybe the handprints or other evidence points to someone else. Wait, the key contradiction might be between Testimony 2 and Testimony 4 by Gregson. 

Soseki says that if the tea was poisoned, the victim couldn't have locked the door. But Gregson says that strychnine's effect is delayed, so the victim could still function and lock the door. 

Wait, but that's actually Gregson supporting the prosecution's case, not contradicting evidence. Let me check the evidences again.

Evidence 7: Victim's Medical Report mentions the poison and other details. If the report confirms strychnine, then Gregson's testimony about its slow-acting nature aligns with that. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 3 (teacup with no tea ring) and Soseki's testimony about giving tea. If Soseki's cup has no tea ring, perhaps indicating he didn't pour the tea, but he claims he brought it as a gift. Wait, maybe the teacup's lack of tea ring suggests the tea wasn't consumed, but if the victim drank it and was poisoned, that contradicts? Hmm, not sure.

Wait, the testimony from Soseki (Testimony 2) says his tea was harmless, so the victim couldn't have been poisoned by that. But if the poison was in the tea, then that's a contradiction. But where's the evidence showing the poison was in the tea?

Alternatively, maybe Evidence 12 (strychnine in Olive's possession) might be the source, but that's another angle.

Wait, looking at Testimony 4 by Gregson: "The victim would have been perfectly able to lock the door after his guest left." This is in response to Soseki's argument that if the tea was poisoned, the victim couldn't have locked the door. Gregson's point is that since strychnine is slow-acting, the victim could still lock the door after Soseki left, implying that Soseki could have poisoned the tea, and the victim locked the door before dying. 

But if Soseki's teacup (his own cup) had no tea ring, maybe indicating he didn't drink, but if the victim's cup had the poison, then Soseki's claim that his tea was harmless could be true, but the poison was in the victim's cup? Or perhaps the victim's cup was poisoned by someone else.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 3 and Soseki's testimony. If Soseki's cup has no tea ring, maybe he didn't pour the tea, but he claims he brought it as a gift. Wait, maybe the tea was in a separate container, and the cups were used to serve it. If Soseki's cup (the one he used) has no tea ring, perhaps he didn't drink from it, but the victim's cup had the poison. But that's not a contradiction yet.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 3 (Gregson says strychnine is slow-acting) and the Medical Report (Evidence 7). But that seems to align.

Wait, looking at the testimonies again:

Testimony 2 from Soseki: "My tea was completely harmless! He couldn't have locked the door behind me otherwise, could he?" 

This implies that if the tea was poisoned, the victim would be incapacitated immediately and couldn't lock the door. But Gregson (Testimony 3 and 4) says strychnine is slow-acting, so the victim could still function. Therefore, Gregson's testimony contradicts Soseki's argument because if the poison was in the tea, the victim could have locked the door, which would support the prosecution's case that Soseki poisoned the tea. 

But the question is which evidence contradicts a testimony. So maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 3 (the teacup's lack of tea ring) and Soseki's testimony that he brought the tea. If the teacup he used had no tea ring, maybe it wasn't used, so he didn't actually pour the tea? Or perhaps the victim's cup had the poison, but the evidence doesn't directly address that. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 12 (Olive has strychnine) and Soseki's testimony, but that's not directly linked unless the poison was hers.

Alternatively, let's see other evidences. Evidence 4 is a torn envelope piece from Shamspeare's room that fits with Miss Green's envelope. If the note in her possession (Evidence 14) was about Duncan Ross, maybe Olive had a motive, but that's a different angle.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 3 and Testimony 0. Soseki says he brought tea as a gift, but if his cup has no tea ring, perhaps he didn't actually pour the tea into the cup, suggesting he didn't give it to the victim. That would contradict his testimony that he gave tea. But the description says "the teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup."

So Soseki's cup (Natsume's) has no tea ring. That would mean he didn't drink from it, but if he brought it as a gift, maybe he poured it into Shamspeare's cup? But then his own cup not having a ring is normal if he didn't drink from it. But if the tea was poisoned, maybe it was in Shamspeare's cup. But the contradiction would be if the medical report shows strychnine came from the tea, but Soseki claims his tea was harmless. However, without direct evidence linking the tea to the poison, maybe that's not it.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (medical report mentions poison) and Testimony 2 where Soseki says his tea was harmless. But that's more of a conflict between his alibi and the evidence, but the question requires an evidence-testimony pair.

Wait, looking at Testimony 3 and 4 by Gregson and the poison's effect. The medical report (Evidence 7) would confirm the poison used. If the medical report states strychnine, then Gregson's testimony aligns with that. 

Alternatively, the contradiction might be between Testimony 2 (Soseki's claim that the tea was harmless) and Evidence 12 (Olive has strychnine), but that's not a direct contradiction unless the poison was hers, but Soseki could still have used it.

Hmm, maybe I'm overcomplicating. Let's look for an evidence that directly contradicts a testimony.

Testimony 4 says the victim could lock the door after Soseki left, implying the poison was in the tea. But if the teacup (Evidence 3) shows that Soseki's cup had no tea ring, maybe indicating he didn't drink, but the victim's cup had the poison. However, the contradiction would be if the poison wasn't in the tea but elsewhere. 

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 5 (soap with a circular depression, which might be a mold for a key or something) and some testimony, but not sure.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says strychnine takes time, so victim could lock door. But if the medical report (Evidence 7) says the poison was something else, that would contradict, but no, the report mentions strychnine.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 3 (teacup's lack of tea ring) and Soseki's testimony that he brought tea as a gift. If the teacup he used (his own) has no tea ring, that suggests he didn't pour the tea into his cup, but maybe he gave it to the victim. However, the description says "the teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume", so each had their own. If Soseki's cup has no tea ring, perhaps he didn't drink, but that's normal if he only poured for the guest. The real contradiction is if the victim's cup also has no tea ring, but that's not stated. 

Alternatively, maybe the victim's cup had the poison, but if there's no tea ring, maybe he didn't drink it. But that's conflicting.

Alternatively, the key contradiction is between Testimony 2 (Soseki says his tea was harmless) and Evidence 12 (Olive's possession of strychnine). But that's not a direct evidence/testimony pair. 

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 3 and Testimony 0. If Soseki brought tea as a gift, then his cup (the one he used) should have a tea ring if he poured it. But his cup has none, implying he didn't use it, so maybe he didn't bring the tea? That would contradict his testimony. 

Ah! That's possible. Let me think again. 

Testimony 0: Soseki says he visited his neighbor with tea as a gift. So he must have poured the tea into the teacups. The teacups used were his and the victim's. His cup (green rim) has no tea ring on the inside. A tea ring would form if the cup was filled and then left with some residue after drinking. If he poured the tea into his own cup (as part of the gift), then the inside would have a ring. But if there's no ring, maybe he didn't actually pour the tea into his cup, suggesting he didn't bring it, contradicting his testimony. 

Therefore, Evidence 3 (teacup with no tea ring) contradicts Testimony 0 (claiming he brought tea as a gift). Because if he brought tea, he would have poured it into his cup, leaving a ring. The absence of the ring implies he didn't pour the tea, hence didn't bring it, contradicting his testimony. 

Alternatively, maybe the tea was in another container, and the cups were used to serve it, so the ring would be on the outside? Not sure. But according to the evidence description, the tea ring is on the inside. So if he didn't have a ring inside his cup, he didn't pour or drink from it, which contradicts his claim of bringing tea. 

Therefore, the answer should be Evidence 3 and Testimony 0.
</think>

Description: The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I'm proud to be the company's East End branch investigator and meter money collection agent.
Person: Metermann
Testimony 1
Testimony: Altamont gas meters accept thruppenny bits, each coin givin' customers about two hours of gorgeous gas!
Person: Metermann
Testimony 2
Testimony: And yet, the meter in Mr Shamspeare's room didn't have a single coin in it!
Person: Altamont
Testimony 3
Testimony: The meter doesn't appear to have been tampered with, though, and the collection agent has the only key.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 4
Testimony: All joints on the meter are welded shut, and the lock is made from solid steel. There's no way to dismantle it.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 5
Testimony: The meter is designed for coins the exact diameter and thickness of a thruppenny bit. Nothing else will fit.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 6
Testimony: Somehow, he's usin' all the flamin' gas he wants without payin' a penny! If that's not thievin', what is?!
Person: Metermann

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me try to work through this step by step. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and they want me to find a pair that contradict each other. I need to make sure I understand each part correctly before jumping to conclusions.

First, let me list out the evidences and testimonies again to have them clear in my mind.

Evidences:
- Evidence 8: Gas Meter. The description says it has a strong lock and a tiny hole in the base of the coin box. This hole might be important because it suggests there's a way to access the coin box despite the lock.

Testimonies from Character 10 (Quinby Altamont):
- Testimony 3: "The meter doesn't appear to have been tampered with, though, and the collection agent has the only key."
- Testimony 4: "The meter is designed with welded joints and a solid steel lock. There's no way to dismantle it."
- Testimony 5: "The meter is designed for coins the exact diameter and thickness of a thruppenny bit. Nothing else will fit."

So, the testimonies from Altamont are emphasizing that the meter is secure, can't be tampered with, and only accepts specific coins. But Evidence 8 mentions there's a tiny hole in the coin box's base. That hole might be a point of contradiction because if there's a hole, maybe someone could access it without needing the key or dismantling the meter, which contradicts the testimony that it couldn't be tampered with.

Wait, but Testimony 3 says the collection agent has the only key, implying that the meter can only be opened with that key. However, the hole in the base (from Evidence 8) might allow someone to tamper without needing the key. That would contradict Testimony 3 and 4, which state it wasn't tampered with and can't be dismantled.

Alternatively, Testimony 5 says nothing else fits except thruppenny bits, but the hole might allow inserting something else, like a tool, to get coins out or bypass the system. But the main contradiction is between the existence of the hole (evidence) and the claim that it can't be tampered with (testimony).

Looking at the possible pairs, the best fit is Evidence 8 and Testimony 3 or 4. Let me check the exact wording again.

Evidence 8's description mentions the coin box has a very strong lock and a tiny hole in its base. The hole's presence might indicate a way to tamper without using the key, which would contradict Testimony 3 (no tampering) and Testimony 4 (can't be dismantled). Since Testimony 3 specifically says it wasn't tampered with, and the hole suggests tampering, that's the contradiction.

So, the correct pair would be Evidence 8 and Testimony 3. Let me confirm there's no other better pair. 

Looking at other evidences, Evidence 5's soap with a depression might relate to the handprints (Evidence 9), but that's not in the testimonies here. The other testimonies from Metermann talk about the coins, but they don't directly conflict with evidence 8's hole. 

Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 8 and Testimony 3.
</think>
